title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 1. (1) These Rules, which may be cited as the Rules of the Superior Courts
text_raw:
1. (1) These Rules, which may be cited as the Rules of the Superior Courts 

(Affidavits) 2021, shall come into operation on the 31st day of March 2021. 

(2) These Rules shall be construed together with the Rules of the Superior 

Courts. 

(3) The Rules of the Superior Courts as amended by these Rules may be 

cited as the Rules of the Superior Courts 1986 to 2021.
text_norm: 1 (1) rule may cited rule superior court (affidavits) 2021 shall come operation 31st day march 2021 (2) rule shall construed together rule superior court (3) rule superior court amended rule may cited rule superior court 1986 2021

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: The Rules of the Superior Courts are amended by the substitution for

2. 

The Rules of the Superior Courts are amended by the substitution for 

Order 40 of the following Order: 

“I.

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 1. Upon any petition, motion, or other application, evidence may be given
text_raw:
1. Upon any petition, motion, or other application, evidence may be given 
by affidavit, but the Court may, on the application of either party, order 
the attendance for cross-examination of the person making any such 
affidavit.
text_norm: 1 upon petition motion application evidence may given affidavit court may application either party order attendance cross-examination person making affidavit

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: Save as otherwise provided by these Rules, all affidavits shall be filed in
text_raw:
2. 

Save as otherwise provided by these Rules, all affidavits shall be filed in 
the Central Office. Affidavits used in proceedings to make a minor a 
ward of Court shall be filed in the Office of Wards of Court. Affidavits 
used in matters of bankruptcy, arrangement, or insolvency where an 
order of adjudication or, as the case may be, a winding up order, has been 
made or in any other case in which an account or inquiry has been 
directed to be taken by the Examiner and a notice to proceed has issued 
in accordance with Order 55, rule 11, shall be filed in the Examiner’s 
Office. Affidavits used in non-contentious probate matters shall be filed 
in the Probate Office.
text_norm: 2 save otherwise provided rule affidavit shall filed central office affidavit used proceeding make minor ward court shall filed office ward court affidavit used matter bankruptcy arrangement insolvency order adjudication case may winding order made case account inquiry directed taken examiner notice proceed issued accordance order 55 rule 11 shall filed examiner office affidavit used non-contentious probate matter shall filed probate office

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: In cases in which an original affidavit is allowed to be used it shall,
text_raw:
3. 

(a) 

In cases in which an original affidavit is allowed to be used it shall, 
at the time when it is used, be delivered to and left with the proper 
officer who shall send it to be filed. 

(b) A copy of an affidavit may in all cases be used, the original 

affidavit having been previously filed, and the copy duly attested. 

(c) A photostatic copy of an original affidavit which has been filed 
may be used, if certified by the solicitor who has filed the same to 
be a true copy thereof and that the original thereof has been filed.
text_norm: 3 (a) case original affidavit allowed used shall time used delivered left proper officer shall send filed (b) copy affidavit may case used original affidavit previously filed copy duly attested (c) photostatic copy original affidavit filed may used certified solicitor filed true copy thereof original thereof filed

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 4. Where a special time is limited for filing affidavits, no affidavit filed
text_raw:
4. Where a special time is limited for filing affidavits, no affidavit filed 

after that time shall be used, unless by leave of the Court.
text_norm: 4 special time limited filing affidavit affidavit filed time shall used unless leave court

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: Except by leave of the Court no order made ex parte in Court founded on
text_raw:
5. 

Except by leave of the Court no order made ex parte in Court founded on 
any affidavit shall be of any force unless the affidavit on which the 
application was made was actually made before the order was applied for 
and [was] produced or filed at the time of making the application. 

Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
“Iris Oifigiúil” of 26th March, 2021. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 4 [127] 

II. 

Form and manner of taking of Affidavits.
text_norm: 5 except leave court order made ex parte court founded affidavit shall force unless affidavit application made actually made order applied produced filed time making application notice making statutory instrument published iris oifigiuil 26th march 2021 4 127 ii form manner taking affidavit

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: In this Order, “officer” other than when referring to the proper officer of
text_raw:
7. 

In this Order, “officer” other than when referring to the proper officer of 
the court means the person taking the affidavit. 

Every affidavit shall be entitled in the cause or matter in which it is 
sworn; but in every case in which there are more than one plaintiff or 
defendant, it shall be sufficient to state the full name of the first plaintiff 
or defendant, respectively, and that there are other plaintiffs or 
defendants as the case may be; and the costs occasioned by any 
unnecessary prolixity in any such title shall be disallowed by the Legal 
Costs Adjudicator.
text_norm: 7 order officer referring proper officer court mean person taking affidavit every affidavit shall entitled cause matter sworn every case one plaintiff defendant shall sufficient state full name first plaintiff defendant respectively plaintiff defendant case may cost occasioned unnecessary prolixity title shall disallowed legal cost adjudicator

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 8. Affidavits shall be confined to such facts as the witness is able of his own
text_raw:
8. Affidavits shall be confined to such facts as the witness is able of his own 
knowledge to prove, and shall state his means of knowledge thereof, 
except on interlocutory motions, on which statements as to his belief, 
with the grounds thereof, may be admitted. The costs of any affidavit 
which shall unnecessarily set forth matters of hearsay or argumentative 
matter, or copies of or extracts from documents, shall not be allowed.
text_norm: 8 affidavit shall confined fact witness able knowledge prove shall state mean knowledge thereof except interlocutory motion statement belief ground thereof may admitted cost affidavit shall unnecessarily set forth matter hearsay argumentative matter copy extract document shall allowed

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) An affidavit taken in the State shall be sworn before a judge,
text_raw:
9. 

(1) An affidavit taken in the State shall be sworn before a judge, 
commissioner to administer oaths, solicitor entitled to exercise the powers 
of a commissioner for oaths or other officer of the court empowered to 
administer oaths. 

(2) An affidavit may be sworn by the deponent- 

(a) 

in the physical presence of the officer before whom it is to be sworn 
or 

(b) where, for reasons stated briefly in the affidavit, it is not practicable 
for the deponent to attend in the physical presence of such officer, by 
video conference with the participation of the deponent and the 
officer, subject to and in accordance with sub-rule (3). 

(3) Where an affidavit is sworn in the manner referred to in sub-rule 

(2)(b), the following conditions shall be complied with - 

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

the officer shall be provided in advance or at the videoconference 
with a copy (which may be in electronic form) of the affidavit, copies 
of any exhibits referred to in it and, in a case where paragraph (c) of 
rule 19(1) applies, a certified copy of the relevant document intended 
to be used to verify the deponent’s identity; 

the officer shall be satisfied that the videoconference facility enables 
the deponent to see and hear the officer and to be seen and heard by 
the officer; 

in a case to which paragraph (b) of rule 19(1) applies, the officer shall 
ensure that the requirement in the paragraph concerned for 
identification of the deponent has been met before the affidavit is 
sworn; 

 
 
 
 [127] 5 

(d) 

(e) 

(f) 

(g) 

the officer shall satisfy himself that the appropriate sacred text for 
taking the oath is available to the deponent; 

during the videoconference and within sight and hearing of the 
officer, the deponent shall produce the original of any relevant 
document intended to be used to verify the deponent’s identity; shall 
identify each page of the affidavit and any and every exhibit referred 
to in it, shall sign or mark any and every exhibit, and shall sign and 
swear the affidavit; 

the sworn affidavit and any and every exhibit referred to in it shall 
immediately following the videoconference be sent to the officer, for 
attestation by the officer; 

the officer shall before attesting the affidavit and signing or marking 
any and every exhibit referred to in it, satisfy himself that the 
document (and each and any exhibit) is the same as that which had 
been identified to him during the videoconference and, where 
relevant, sign and append to the affidavit the certified copy of the 
relevant document used to verify the deponent’s identity, and 

(h) notwithstanding rule 6, the jurat of the affidavit shall indicate the date 
on which the affidavit was made by the deponent, the place at which 
the officer was when taking the affidavit and the fact that the affidavit 
was sworn using a videoconference. 

(4) In sub-rule (3) and in rule 19, “videoconference” includes any 
connection of two or more persons at different locations by means of 
information and communications technology or combination of such 
technologies which enables persons remote from one another both to see 
and hear and to be seen and be heard by one another in real time.
text_norm: 9 (1) affidavit taken state shall sworn judge commissioner administer oath solicitor entitled exercise power commissioner oath officer court empowered administer oath (2) affidavit may sworn deponent- (a) physical presence officer sworn (b) reason stated briefly affidavit practicable deponent attend physical presence officer video conference participation deponent officer subject accordance sub-rule (3) (3) affidavit sworn manner referred sub-rule (2)(b) following condition shall complied - (a) (b) (c) officer shall provided advance videoconference copy (which may electronic form) affidavit copy exhibit referred case paragraph (c) rule 19(1) applies certified copy relevant document intended used verify deponent identity officer shall satisfied videoconference facility enables deponent see hear officer seen heard officer case paragraph (b) rule 19(1) applies officer shall ensure requirement paragraph concerned identification deponent met affidavit sworn 127 5 (d) (e) (f) (g) officer shall satisfy appropriate sacred text taking oath available deponent videoconference within sight hearing officer deponent shall produce original relevant document intended used verify deponent identity shall identify page affidavit every exhibit referred shall sign mark every exhibit shall sign swear affidavit sworn affidavit every exhibit referred shall immediately following videoconference sent officer attestation officer officer shall attesting affidavit signing marking every exhibit referred satisfy document (and exhibit) identified videoconference relevant sign append affidavit certified copy relevant document used verify deponent identity (h) notwithstanding rule 6 jurat affidavit shall indicate date affidavit made deponent place officer taking affidavit fact affidavit sworn using videoconference (4) sub-rule (3) rule 19 videoconference includes connection two person different location mean information communication technology combination technology enables person remote one another see hear seen heard one another real time

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) Every person empowered by law to administer an oath shall express
text_raw:
10. 

(1) Every person empowered by law to administer an oath shall express 
the date on which and the place where he takes any affidavit. 

(2) Every person empowered by law to administer an oath shall express 
the date on which and the place where and, where necessary in the 
circumstances, the time when, he takes the acknowledgement of any deed, 
or recognisance, otherwise the same shall not be held authentic, nor be 
admitted to be filed or enrolled without the leave of the Court. 

(3) Every such person shall express the date on which, the time when, and 
the place where, he does any other act incident to his office.
text_norm: 10 (1) every person empowered law administer oath shall express date place take affidavit (2) every person empowered law administer oath shall express date place necessary circumstance time take acknowledgement deed recognisance otherwise shall held authentic admitted filed enrolled without leave court (3) every person shall express date time place act incident office

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 11. All examinations, affidavits, declarations, affirmations and attestations of
text_raw:
11. All examinations, affidavits, declarations, affirmations and attestations of 
honour in causes or matters pending in the High Court, or the Court of 
Appeal or the Supreme Court, and also acknowledgements required for 
the purpose of enrolling any deed in the said Courts, may be taken in any 
foreign country or place before any Irish diplomatic or consular 
representative or agent exercising his functions in that country or place 
or, when there is no such representative or agent or no such 
representative or agent conveniently near to the deponent in such country 

 
 
 
 6 [127] 

or place, before any notary public lawfully authorised to administer oaths 
in that country or place, or where such country or place is a part of the 
Commonwealth of Nations or a British possession, before any judge, 
court, notary public or person authorised to administer oaths in such part 
or possession; and the Judges and officers of the High Court, and of the 
Court of Appeal and of the Supreme Court shall take judicial notice of 
the seal or signature, as the case may be, of any such diplomatic or 
consular representative or agent, judge, court, notary public or other 
person attached, appended or subscribed to any such examination, 
affidavit, 
or 
acknowledgement, or to any other deed or document. 

affirmation, 

declaration, 

attestation 

honour, 

of
text_norm: 11 examination affidavit declaration affirmation attestation honour cause matter pending high court court appeal supreme court also acknowledgement required purpose enrolling deed said court may taken foreign country place irish diplomatic consular representative agent exercising function country place representative agent representative agent conveniently near deponent country 6 127 place notary public lawfully authorised administer oath country place country place part commonwealth nation british possession judge court notary public person authorised administer oath part possession judge officer high court court appeal supreme court shall take judicial notice seal signature case may diplomatic consular representative agent judge court notary public person attached appended subscribed examination affidavit acknowledgement deed document affirmation declaration attestation honour

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 12. Every affidavit shall be drawn up in the first person and shall be divided
text_raw:
12. Every affidavit shall be drawn up in the first person and shall be divided 
into paragraphs and every paragraph shall be numbered consecutively, 
and as nearly as may be shall be confined to a distinct portion of the 
subject matter. Every affidavit shall be written or printed book-wise. No 
costs shall be allowed for any affidavit or part of an affidavit 
substantially departing from this rule.
text_norm: 12 every affidavit shall drawn first person shall divided paragraph every paragraph shall numbered consecutively nearly may shall confined distinct portion subject matter every affidavit shall written printed book-wise cost shall allowed affidavit part affidavit substantially departing rule

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) Every affidavit shall state the description, trade, profession or
text_raw:
13. 

(1) Every affidavit shall state the description, trade, profession or 
employment of the deponent and: 

(i) 

the deponent’s place of business, 
employment, or 

trade, profession or 

(ii) 

the true place of abode of the deponent.
text_norm: 13 (1) every affidavit shall state description trade profession employment deponent (i) deponent place business employment trade profession (ii) true place abode deponent

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: In every affidavit made by two or more deponents the names of the
text_raw:
14. 

In every affidavit made by two or more deponents the names of the 
several persons making the affidavit shall be inserted in the jurat, except 
that if the affidavit of all the deponents is taken at one time by the same 
officer it shall be sufficient to state that it was sworn by both (or all) of 
the “above-named deponents”.
text_norm: 14 every affidavit made two deponent name several person making affidavit shall inserted jurat except affidavit deponent taken one time officer shall sufficient state sworn (or all) above-named deponent

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 15. There shall be on every affidavit a note showing on whose behalf it is
text_raw:
15. There shall be on every affidavit a note showing on whose behalf it is 
filed, and no affidavit shall be filed or used without such note, unless the 
Court shall otherwise direct.
text_norm: 15 shall every affidavit note showing whose behalf filed affidavit shall filed used without note unless court shall otherwise direct

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 16. The Court may order to be struck out from any affidavit any matter
text_raw:
16. The Court may order to be struck out from any affidavit any matter 
which is scandalous and may order the costs of any application to strike 
out such matter to be paid as between solicitor and client.
text_norm: 16 court may order struck affidavit matter scandalous may order cost application strike matter paid solicitor client

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 17. No affidavit having in the jurat or body thereof any interlineation,
text_raw:
17. No affidavit having in the jurat or body thereof any interlineation, 
alteration, or erasure, shall without leave of the Court be filed, read, or 
made use of in any matter pending in Court unless the interlineation or 
alteration (other than by erasure) is authenticated by the initials of the 
person taking the affidavit, nor, in the case of an erasure, unless the 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [127] 7 

words or figures appearing at the time of taking the affidavit to be written 
on the erasure are re-written and signed or initialled in the margin of the 
affidavit by the person taking it.
text_norm: 17 affidavit jurat body thereof interlineation alteration erasure shall without leave court filed read made use matter pending court unless interlineation alteration (other erasure) authenticated initial person taking affidavit case erasure unless 127 7 word figure appearing time taking affidavit written erasure re-written signed initialled margin affidavit person taking it

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) Subject to rule 19, where an intending deponent is not capable of
text_raw:
18. 

(1) Subject to rule 19, where an intending deponent is not capable of 
making an affidavit in one of the official languages of the State, he or she 
shall make an affidavit in another language which he understands (in this 
rule and rules 19 and 20 referred to as a “foreign language affidavit”). 

(2) A foreign language affidavit shall be translated into one of the 
official languages of the State by a translator who is suitably qualified for 
the purpose. 

(3) Where a foreign language affidavit is to be filed or lodged in court, 
an affidavit of the translator shall (as the case may be) be filed or lodged 
at the same time in which: 

(i) 

the translator sets out his qualifications as a translator, 

(ii) 

a copy of the foreign language affidavit and the original 
translation referred to in sub-rule (2) are exhibited, and 

(iii) 

the translator confirms that the translation is accurate. 

(4) The original translation referred to in sub-rule (2) shall in addition be 
filed or lodged with the affidavit of the translator referred to in sub-rule 
(3).
text_norm: 18 (1) subject rule 19 intending deponent capable making affidavit one official language state shall make affidavit another language understands (in rule rule 19 20 referred foreign language affidavit ) (2) foreign language affidavit shall translated one official language state translator suitably qualified purpose (3) foreign language affidavit filed lodged court affidavit translator shall (as case may be) filed lodged time (i) translator set qualification translator (ii) copy foreign language affidavit original translation referred sub-rule (2) exhibited (iii) translator confirms translation accurate (4) original translation referred sub-rule (2) shall addition filed lodged affidavit translator referred sub-rule (3)

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) A person taking an affidavit shall certify in the jurat of every
text_raw:
19. 

(1) A person taking an affidavit shall certify in the jurat of every 
affidavit taken by him: 

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

that he personally knows the deponent, or 

that the deponent has been identified to him by some person 
personally known to him and named in the jurat who certifies his 
personal knowledge of the deponent, or 

that the identity of the deponent has been established by him by 
reference to a relevant document containing a photograph of the 
deponent before the affidavit was taken, 

and in a case to which paragraph (c) applies shall give particulars of the 
relevant document concerned. 

(2) A person taking an affidavit shall, where it appears to him that the 
affidavit is to be sworn by any person who appears to be illiterate or 
blind: 

(a) 

(b) 

ensure that the affidavit is read in his presence to the deponent and 
that the deponent has fully understood it, 

in any case where the deponent appears not to be capable of 
understanding one of the official languages of the State, ensure that 
the affidavit is made as a foreign language affidavit in accordance 
with rule 18 and is read to the deponent by a suitably qualified 

 
 
 
 8 [127] 

interpreter in the presence of the person taking the affidavit, and 
that the deponent has fully understood it, and 

(c) 

certify in the jurat that the affidavit was read in his presence to the 
deponent (in a case to which paragraph (b) refers, by a suitably 
qualified interpreter), that the deponent fully understood it and that 
the deponent made his signature or mark in his presence. 

(3) Where a foreign language affidavit is to be filed or lodged in court in 
a case to which paragraph (b) of sub-rule (2) refers, in addition to the 
translator’s affidavit referred to in rule 18(3) an affidavit of the 
interpreter shall (as the case may be) be filed or lodged at the same time 
in which the interpreter sets out his qualifications as an interpreter, 
exhibits a copy of the foreign language affidavit and confirms that he 
read accurately to the deponent the contents of the foreign language 
affidavit, provided that where the translator and interpreter are one and 
the same person, a single affidavit may be sworn by that person for the 
purposes of rule 18(3) and this sub-rule. 

(4) In this rule “relevant document” has the same meaning as in section 
2 of the Statutory Declarations Act 1938. 

(5) Notwithstanding sub-rule (2), where an affidavit to which paragraph 
(a) or (b) of sub-rule (2) applies is intended to be made by videoconference 
in accordance with rule 9(3), the affidavit concerned may be read to the 
deponent by videoconference during the videoconference at which the 
affidavit concerned is sworn.

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (1) No foreign language affidavit shall be used in evidence in the
text_raw:
20. 

(1) No foreign language affidavit shall be used in evidence in the 
absence of the affidavit referred to in rule 18(3). 

(2) No affidavit referred to in rule 19(2) shall be used in evidence in the 
absence of the certificate referred to in paragraph (c) of rule 19(2) and 
(where applicable) in default of filing of the interpreter’s affidavit 
referred to in rule 14(3), unless the Court is otherwise satisfied that the 
affidavit was read over to and fully understood by the deponent.

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 21. Rules 18 and 20 shall be without prejudice to section 20(3) of the
text_raw:
21. Rules 18 and 20 shall be without prejudice to section 20(3) of the 

European Arrest Warrant Act 2003.
text_norm: 21 rule 18 20 shall without prejudice section 20(3) european arrest warrant act 2003

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 22. The Court may receive any affidavit sworn for the purpose of being used
text_raw:
22. The Court may receive any affidavit sworn for the purpose of being used 
in any cause or matter notwithstanding any defect by misdescription of 
parties or otherwise in the title or jurat, or any other irregularity in the 
form thereof, and may direct a memorandum to be made on the document 
that it has been so received.
text_norm: 22 court may receive affidavit sworn purpose used cause matter notwithstanding defect misdescription party otherwise title jurat irregularity form thereof may direct memorandum made document received

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 23. No affidavit shall be sufficient if sworn before the solicitor acting for the
text_raw:
23. No affidavit shall be sufficient if sworn before the solicitor acting for the 
party on whose behalf the affidavit is to be used, or before any agent or 
correspondent of such solicitor or before the party himself. 

 
 
 
 
 
 [127] 9
text_norm: 23 affidavit shall sufficient sworn solicitor acting party whose behalf affidavit used agent correspondent solicitor party himself 127 9

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 24. Any affidavit which would be insufficient if sworn before the solicitor
text_raw:
24. Any affidavit which would be insufficient if sworn before the solicitor 

himself shall be insufficient if sworn before his clerk or partner. 

III. Particular types of affidavit
text_norm: 24 affidavit would insufficient sworn solicitor shall insufficient sworn clerk partner iii particular type affidavit

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 25. Every affidavit of service shall state when, where, and how, and by whom,
text_raw:
25. Every affidavit of service shall state when, where, and how, and by whom, 
such service was effected and in the case of delivery to any person, shall 
state that the deponent was at the time of such delivery acquainted with the 
appearance of such person or by what means the person was identified to 
the deponent.
text_norm: 25 every affidavit service shall state service effected case delivery person shall state deponent time delivery acquainted appearance person mean person identified deponent

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 26. Where an injunction or order not to leave the jurisdiction has been
text_raw:
26. Where an injunction or order not to leave the jurisdiction has been 
granted or made, the party applying for such injunction or order shall 
furnish copies of the affidavits grounding the same to any party affected 
thereby upon demand and payment therefor at the rate specified in Order
text_norm: 26 injunction order leave jurisdiction granted made party applying injunction order shall furnish copy affidavit grounding party affected thereby upon demand payment therefor rate specified order

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 27. The consent of a trustee to act shall be sufficiently evidenced by a written
text_raw:
27. The consent of a trustee to act shall be sufficiently evidenced by a written 
consent signed by him and verified by the signature of his solicitor or the 
applicant’s solicitor. 

IV. Affidavits and evidence before the Master or the Examiner
text_norm: 27 consent trustee act shall sufficiently evidenced written consent signed verified signature solicitor applicant solicitor iv affidavit evidence master examiner

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 28. The party intending to use any affidavit in support of any application
text_raw:
28. The party intending to use any affidavit in support of any application 
made before the Master or before the Examiner shall give notice to the 
other parties concerned of his intention in that behalf.
text_norm: 28 party intending use affidavit support application made master examiner shall give notice party concerned intention behalf

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 29. All affidavits which have been previously made and read in Court upon
text_raw:
29. All affidavits which have been previously made and read in Court upon 
any proceeding in a cause or matter may be used before the Master or the 
Examiner.
text_norm: 29 affidavit previously made read court upon proceeding cause matter may used master examiner

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 30. Every alteration in an account verified by affidavit to be used before the
text_raw:
30. Every alteration in an account verified by affidavit to be used before the 
Master or before the Examiner shall be marked with the initials of the 
person before whom the affidavit is sworn, and such alterations shall not 
be made by erasure.
text_norm: 30 every alteration account verified affidavit used master examiner shall marked initial person affidavit sworn alteration shall made erasure

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 31. Accounts, extracts from parish registers, particulars of creditors’ debts,
text_raw:
31. Accounts, extracts from parish registers, particulars of creditors’ debts, 
and other documents referred to by affidavit shall not be annexed to the 
affidavit, or referred to in the affidavit as annexed, but shall be referred to 
as exhibits. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10 [127]

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 32. Every certificate on an exhibit referred to in an affidavit signed by the
text_raw:
32. Every certificate on an exhibit referred to in an affidavit signed by the 
person before whom the affidavit is sworn shall be marked with the short 
title of the cause or matter. 

V. 

Trial on affidavit

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 33. Within fourteen days after a consent for taking evidence by affidavit as
text_raw:
33. Within fourteen days after a consent for taking evidence by affidavit as 
between the parties has been given, or after an order has been made for 
such purpose, or within such time as the parties may agree upon, or the 
Court may allow, the plaintiff shall file his affidavits and deliver to the 
defendant or his solicitor a list thereof.
text_norm: 33 within fourteen day consent taking evidence affidavit party given order made purpose within time party may agree upon court may allow plaintiff shall file affidavit deliver defendant solicitor list thereof

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 34. The defendant, within fourteen days after delivery of such list, or within
text_raw:
34. The defendant, within fourteen days after delivery of such list, or within 
such time as the parties may agree upon, or the Court may allow, shall 
file his affidavits, and deliver to the plaintiff or his solicitor a list thereof.
text_norm: 34 defendant within fourteen day delivery list within time party may agree upon court may allow shall file affidavit deliver plaintiff solicitor list thereof

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 35. Within seven days after the expiration of the last-mentioned fourteen
text_raw:
35. Within seven days after the expiration of the last-mentioned fourteen 
days, or such other time as aforesaid, the plaintiff shall file his affidavits 
in reply, which affidavits shall be confined to matters strictly in reply, 
and shall deliver to the defendant or his solicitor a list thereof.
text_norm: 35 within seven day expiration last-mentioned fourteen day time aforesaid plaintiff shall file affidavit reply affidavit shall confined matter strictly reply shall deliver defendant solicitor list thereof

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 36. When the evidence is taken by affidavit, any party desiring to crossexamine a deponent who has made an affidavit filed on behalf of the
text_raw:
36. When the evidence is taken by affidavit, any party desiring to crossexamine a deponent who has made an affidavit filed on behalf of the 
opposite party may serve upon the party by whom such affidavit has been 
filed a notice in writing, requiring the production of the deponent for 
cross-examination at the trial, such notice to be served at any time before 
the expiration of fourteen days next after the end of the time allowed for 
filing affidavits in reply, or within such time as in any case the Court may 
specially appoint; and unless such deponent is produced accordingly, his 
affidavit shall not be used as evidence unless by the leave of the Court. 
The party producing such deponent for cross-examination shall not be 
entitled to demand the expenses thereof in the first instance from the 
party requiring such production. The notice shall be in the Form No 21 
in Appendix C.
text_norm: 36 evidence taken affidavit party desiring crossexamine deponent made affidavit filed behalf opposite party may serve upon party affidavit filed notice writing requiring production deponent cross-examination trial notice served time expiration fourteen day next end time allowed filing affidavit reply within time case court may specially appoint unless deponent produced accordingly affidavit shall used evidence unless leave court party producing deponent cross-examination shall entitled demand expense thereof first instance party requiring production notice shall form 21 appendix c

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 37. The party to whom such notice as is mentioned in rule 36, is given shall
text_raw:
37. The party to whom such notice as is mentioned in rule 36, is given shall 
be entitled to compel the attendance of the deponent for crossexamination in the same way as he might compel the attendance of a 
witness to be examined.
text_norm: 37 party notice mentioned rule 36 given shall entitled compel attendance deponent crossexamination way might compel attendance witness examined

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 38. When the evidence under this Order is taken by affidavit, the notice of
text_raw:
38. When the evidence under this Order is taken by affidavit, the notice of 
trial shall be given at the same time after the expiry of the time limited by 
rule 34 as is by these Rules provided after the close of the pleadings; 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [127] 11 

provided that other affidavits may be used if all the parties interested 
consent thereto, or the Court so orders.
text_norm: 38 evidence order taken affidavit notice trial shall given time expiry time limited rule 34 rule provided close pleading 127 11 provided affidavit may used party interested consent thereto court order

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: 39. Save where otherwise provided this Order applies to affidavits whether
text_raw:
39. Save where otherwise provided this Order applies to affidavits whether 

sworn within or outside the State.” 

 
 
 
 
 
 12 [127]

title: section 36, the Courts of Justice Act, 1936, section 68 (as applied by the Courts
heading: (This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Rules amend Order 40 of the Rules of the Superior Courts to provide for 
remote swearing of affidavits and the use of a business address by a deponent 
where appropriate.
